TextEquiv.Unicode: loose at randon to the blaspheming of
Gods glory, or hurt of our neighbour.
Let the talke of a Christian man bee
honest, profitable, and seasoned with
salt, let it bee unacquainted with scof
fing, lightnesse, lying, ribauldrie,
and filthinesse. S. James in the third
Chapter of his Epistle hath spoken
sufficiently of the tongues properties.
In his first Chapter also hee saieth:
Let everie man bee swift to heare.
flowe to speake, and flowe to anger.
And Paul sayeth: Let no filthie com
munication proceede out of your
mouth, but that which is good to e
difie withall, as oft as neede is, that
it maye minister grace unto the hea
rers, and greeve not the holie spirite
of God, by whom yee are sealed un
to the daye of Redemption. And a
gayne: Let not fornication, or anye
uncleannesse, or covetousnesse, bee
once named among you, as it be
commeth Saintes. Neither filthinesse,
nor foolish talking, neyther jesting,
which are not seemely, but rather gi
ving of thankes. Let no man deceive
you with vayne wordes. For, for such
thinges commeth the wrath of God
uppon the children of disobedience.
For in another place hee citeth this
sentence out of Menander and saith:
Ill woordes corrupt good manners.
Moreover a mans minde is bewrayed
by his talke: for of the hearts aboun
dance the mouth doth speake. If ther
fore in any thing then in tongue especi
al it behoveth Christians to be sober &
continent.
The Lord (I confesse) hath graun
ted man the use of certayn pleasures.
For he may lawfully without offence
to God, cloath his body with garmets
soberly, thereby to keepe his limmes
from colde. God hath and doeth allowe
the embracinges of man and wife, in

loose at randon to the blaspheming of Gods glory, or hurt of our neighbour. Let the talke of a Christian man bee honest, profitable, and seasoned with salt, let it bee unacquainted with scof fing, lightnesse, lying, ribauldrie, and filthinesse. S. James in the third Chapter of his Epistle hath spoken sufficiently of the tongues properties. In his first Chapter also hee saieth: Let everie man bee swift to heare. flowe to speake, and flowe to anger. And Paul sayeth: Let no filthie com munication proceede out of your mouth, but that which is good to e difie withall, as oft as neede is, that it maye minister grace unto the hea rers, and greeve not the holie spirite of God, by whom yee are sealed un to the daye of Redemption. And a gayne: Let not fornication, or anye uncleannesse, or covetousnesse, bee once named among you, as it be commeth Saintes. Neither filthinesse, nor foolish talking, neyther jesting, which are not seemely, but rather gi ving of thankes. Let no man deceive you with vayne wordes. For, for such thinges commeth the wrath of God uppon the children of disobedience. For in another place hee citeth this sentence out of Menander and saith: Ill woordes corrupt good manners. Moreover a mans minde is bewrayed by his talke: for of the hearts aboun dance the mouth doth speake. If ther fore in any thing then in tongue especi al it behoveth Christians to be sober & continent. The Lord (I confesse) hath graun ted man the use of certayn pleasures. For he may lawfully without offence to God, cloath his body with garmets soberly, thereby to keepe his limmes from colde. God hath and doeth allowe the embracinges of man and wife, in
holy wedlocke. Hee graunteth choyce
of a dwelling place coveniently situa
ted against the untemperatenesse of
the ayre, and biddeth us not to wan
der like beastes and cattell, through
fields and desolate woods. Hee hath for
our necessitie and pleasaunt feeding,
allowed us the use of meate & drinke.
Hee graunteth us quietnesse, ease and
sleepe, which doth wonderfully refresh
the strength that is decayed and tyred
with paynes. Therefore so often as
a godly man doth enjoy them, doth use
them, and is delighted with the honest
pleasure of them, let him give thanks
to God, and use them moderatly in the
feare of the Lorde. For in so doing hee
sinneth not against the Lorde: but by
the abuse of those thinges, by unthak
fulnes for them, and by immoderate u
sing of them, he doeth offend his God &
maker.
For what is allowed or permitted
to married folkes, I have already de
clared in this verie sermon so that I
neede not heare againe to repeat it un
to you. Solomon saith: Be glad with
the wife of thy youth: let her be as the
beloved Hinde and plesaunt Roe: let
her love alwaies refresh thee, and bee
thou still delighted therein, &c. In the
meane time let every one refrain from
all abuse and intemperancie: and if
necessitie at any time require it, let
man and wife lie asunder, as Paul do
eth counsell them: or else let them give
care to the Prophet Joel, who saieth:
Proclaim an holy fast, gather the peo
ple together: let the bridegrome come
forth of his chamber, and the bride out
of his closet.
Our garments must bee cleanely
and honest according to our countrie
fashion to cover and become us, unles
our countrie fashion be too farre out of
order: there must bee in them no hy

holy wedlocke. Hee graunteth choyce of a dwelling place coveniently situa ted against the untemperatenesse of the ayre, and biddeth us not to wan der like beastes and cattell, through fields and desolate woods. Hee hath for our necessitie and pleasaunt feeding, allowed us the use of meate & drinke. Hee graunteth us quietnesse, ease and sleepe, which doth wonderfully refresh the strength that is decayed and tyred with paynes. Therefore so often as a godly man doth enjoy them, doth use them, and is delighted with the honest pleasure of them, let him give thanks to God, and use them moderatly in the feare of the Lorde. For in so doing hee sinneth not against the Lorde: but by the abuse of those thinges, by unthak fulnes for them, and by immoderate u sing of them, he doeth offend his God & maker. For what is allowed or permitted to married folkes, I have already de clared in this verie sermon so that I neede not heare againe to repeat it un to you. Solomon saith: Be glad with the wife of thy youth: let her be as the beloved Hinde and plesaunt Roe: let her love alwaies refresh thee, and bee thou still delighted therein, &c. In the meane time let every one refrain from all abuse and intemperancie: and if necessitie at any time require it, let man and wife lie asunder, as Paul do eth counsell them: or else let them give care to the Prophet Joel, who saieth: Proclaim an holy fast, gather the peo ple together: let the bridegrome come forth of his chamber, and the bride out of his closet. Our garments must bee cleanely and honest according to our countrie fashion to cover and become us, unles our countrie fashion be too farre out of order: there must bee in them no hy
